name: cork forestry | cleft timber, measured as dry mass | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/13407/documentation

The datasets covers cork production in an silvipastoral extensive management system as common in Portugal. The dataset refers to the yield of 1 hectare over the rotation period of 140 as the maximum rotation period in commercial cork production in Portugal.

Includes manual harvesting of the cork (every 9 years) and motor-manual processes for thinning and final cutting of the trees. Also included are the transport of the workers to the forests for harvesting cork and the transport of the products to the nearest forest road.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/023:Gathering of non-wood forest products/0230:Gathering of non-wood forest products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: cork yield data from yield table (Batista et al. 2012; see exchanges for details on source)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: data for Germany used for the forestry processes
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The harvesting of wood considers the motor-manual processes for 'Buche, II. Ertragsklasse, starke Durchforstung'

exchanges.description: Yield over one rotation of 140 years in Mg converted to kg

flow.name: cleft timber, measured as dry mass
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/022:Logging/0220:Logging

exchanges.description: dataset refers to 1 ha  (=10000 m2/ha) over one rotation. Cork production is a silvipastoral activity; according to the source, only 2% of Portuguese cork forests reach a crown cover of > 50%; thus it is assumed that on average 45% of the area is dedicated to cork production whereas the other 55% of the land are dedicated to pastoral activities.
Total dry mass converted to carbon (0.494 kg C/kg dry wood) and converted to CO2 via molar relationship
total dry mass x gross calorific value of hardwood

flow.name: Energy, gross calorific value, in biomass

exchanges.description: value for power sawing for final harvest per kg cork from ecoinvent 2.2, multiplied with total yield over one rotation and extrapolated to total power sawing per hectare, assuming that final harvest yields 1/3 of total wood harvest over one rotation period; source: Kellenberger, D., H.-J. Althaus, T. Künniger, M. Lehmann, N. Jungbluth and P. Thalmann (2007): Life cycle inventories of building products. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 7, EMPA Duebendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, CH.

flow.name: power sawing, without catalytic converter
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/16:Manufacture of wood and of products of wood and cork, except furniture; manufacture of articles of straw and plaiting materials/161:Sawmilling and planing of wood/1610:Sawmilling and planing of wood

exchanges.description: dataset refers to 1 ha  (=10000 m2/ha) over one rotation. Cork production is a silvipastoral activity; according to the source, only 2% of Portuguese cork forests reach a crown cover of > 50%; thus it is assumed that on average 45% of the area is dedicated to cork production whereas the other 55% of the land are dedicated to pastoral activities.

Dataset refers to 1 ha (=10000 m2/ha) over one rotation with a commercial rotation length of 140 years. According to the source, only 2% of Portuguese cork forests reach a crown cover of > 50%; thus it is assumed that on average 45% of the area is dedicated to cork production whereas the other 55% of the land are dedicated to pastoral activities.

value for transport of workers (for manual debarking) per kg cork from ecoinvent 2.2, multiplied with total yield over one rotation; source: Kellenberger, D., H.-J. Althaus, T. Künniger, M. Lehmann, N. Jungbluth and P. Thalmann (2007): Life cycle inventories of building products. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 7, EMPA Duebendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, CH.
